Articles.Content:
This is not so much a full mission report as a happy player breathing a sigh of relief.

I installed KSP 2 months ago and have loved every minute of it. Even when rockets tore themselves apart or flipped end over end it teaches you something about the game. I've opened up most of the tech tree and have mined the Mun and Minmus just because it's a new challenge. Sure it can be frustrating when your "carefully" planned deployment system sends your rover crashing into the grond the moment you remember you haven't saved in ages. Or you hit Z and nothing happens because the Sun has been at just the wrong angle and you've run out of power. It's all on the learning curve.

But then....

Having checked for any upcoming transfer windows for my first steps outside the the local neighbourhood, I found the next one was for Moho (I'm currently at Y2 D307 if memory serves). Not the easiest of targets from what I've read. So, I built three identical science probes, Alf, Betty and Cecil (not every name has to be "K" centric!) and sent them off using various figures I've found online. Having now done the burn to match inclination, I'm delighted to report that 2 out of 3 are on target for Moho SOI. Alf, sadly, has missed the mark and will probably lack the Ã¢Ë†â€ v to get things back on track.

Betty and Cecil on the other hand are heading for an encounter. Some minor tweaks should line things up nicely. Discovering this happy fact was one of those great moments in gaming, when you find yourself grinning like a space crazy Kerbal.

I've not used any Mods so its been down to pen and paper and a keen eye on the time/date as I've also been landing a base on Minmus. The other big resource I've relied on has been these forums with a wealth of answers and ideas. Thank you to everyone who helped make the above possible. It would have taken a lot longer without you.

/cheers

Edited September 18, 2015 by Clipperride
Uodate
That's good stuff Clipperride! Moho is darn hard, in all the saves and all the versions I've played I have not gotten down and up without a bit of cheating.

Thank you. I'm not planning a landing on this trip. It was more just a test to see if I could use the various transfer window calculators available online.

Love your graphic novels by the way Kuzzter! Long may Kerbfleet continue....... :-)

Some good news in from the Kerbal Deep Space Network. Moho Probe Cecil, despite being the last to leave, was the first to reach Moho. Due to the approach speed it turned into a flyby mission. The data was collected during a close approach of ~60km and sent back as Ceci rushed on by. Betty will be next and in an attempt to bring the Ã¢Ë†â€ v down to a manageable level for capture, she will be passing by at just 6,500 m.

EDIT:- Departure was Y2 D253 and arrival was Y2 D365. I'm quite pleased with my very first attempt at Interplanetary travel.

Edited September 16, 2015 by Clipperride

Whoa! Moho? Now that's a hard target Word of advice from a guy, who in a moment of apparent mental impairement decided to build a space station around that nasty piece of rock: If your transit through Moho's SoI is going to be short, start burning retrograde way ahead of periapsis. I had ships zip past Moho back into Kerbol orbit despite having enough dV for capture. Encounter was simply too short for nuclear-driven ships with low Thrust-to-Weight ratio.

CheersCheers Scotius. You're right, the probe whipped through Mohos SOI, so I will be starting the burn for the next probe to reach the system very early! (Y2 D389). I'm glad I launched three identical probes as the first missed its target, the second has taught me a lot and, hopefully, the third will be able to achieve orbit.

Edited September 17, 2015 by Clipperride

The final probe in the series arrived at Moho last night. Unfortunately, it started it's burn a little too early (I blame the probe core rather than user incompetence), reducing its Peri to a fatally low altitude, some way below the planets surface.

On the plus side, the probe returned data from under 50,000m which was transmitted shortly before impact, gaining some more Science. It also returned a couple of nice pictures before becoming one with Moho.

Here are a couple:-

Too late to change course

A second before impact......

The final haunting message. Then the link goes dead

Fairwell Alfie, Betty and Cecil

Edit:- The mission time is longer than the journey to Moho as the probes were launched into a station keeping LKO a while before the transfer window opened.

Edited September 19, 2015 by Clipperride
